item.title: Create a NoSQL Database Using MySQL Document Store
item.description:
SQL + NoSQL = MySQL

MySQL, the world’s most popular database management system (DBMS) has been rightfully used purely to create and manage relational databases until recently. During the last decade, due to the requirements to store large quantities of diverse data, we've seen the rise in adoption and usage of NoSQL databases.

In MySQL version 5.7.12, MySQL Document Store was introduced, enabling MySQL to act as a NoSQL JSON Document Store. MySQL is thereby both a relational and a NoSQL DBMS.

Though there are many types of NoSQL databases with varying features, they have all steered clear of the relational data model and are all schemaless by definition. There are mainly four categories of NoSQL databases.

Key-value Pair NoSQL DB: They store data in key/value pairs. For instance, Amazon's Dynamo and Redis are in this category.

Column or wide column NoSQL DB: In column-based NoSQL databases, columns don't have to be consistent across records. You can add columns to specific rows without having to add them to every single record. Google's BigTable, Apache Cassandra are examples of column-based databases.

Graph-Based NoSQL DB: They store data as well the relations amongst them. This model is based on graph theory where structures are composed of vertices and edges. An entity is stored as a node (vertex) with the relationship as edges. Neo4J, Infinite Graph, OrientDB, FlockDB are some examples graph-based databases.

And finally Document-based NoSQL DB: They store data as documents using JSON or XML formats. Amazon SimpleDB, CouchDB, MongoDB, are examples of popular document-based NoSQL DBMS. MySQL Document Store belongs to this last category.

The advent of MySQL Document Store starts with the support for native JSON data type in MySQL 5.7.8. This feature enables efficient access to JSON documents stored in MySQL databases. On top of this feature, MySQL Document Store was built, a pure document store solution and was introduced in MySQL 5.7.12.

Currently when you're considering database solutions, you are forced to make a choice or combine multiple solutions – SQL/NoSQL, Relational/Document Store. MySQL folks thought why not build both into MySQL database. SQL and NoSQL build into one solution. Hence SQL + NoSQL = MySQL...?? They are not only built into the database storage, but across all levels for the database stack – storage, structure, protocol, APIs, Tools, etc. And that’s what has been materialized with the release of

  • X Plugin in MySQL 5.7.12
  • X Dev API
  • MySQL connectors: Connector/C++, Connector/Java, Connector/Node.js, Connector/NET, Connector/Python
  • MySQL Shell: provides implementations of X DevAPI in JavaScript and Python

With this 2-in-1 solution, you can have both schemaless and schema data models in the same technology stack.

X Protocol, X Plugin, and X DevAPI

X Protocol

MySQL has introduced a new protocol called X Protocol, which is used for communications between MySQL Clients and a MySQL Server. It is based on Google Protocol Buffers and supports asynchronous communication to the server. The X Protocol is optimized for CRUD as well as SQL API operations.

X Plugin

X Plugin is the MySQL Server plugin which enables client/server communication using the X Protocol. It enables you to use MySQL as a document store. Clients that implement X DevAPI, in other support the X Protocol, can communicate with MySQL server and issue CRUD requests and send to and receive JSON from the server.

To verify that X Plugin is installed on an instance of MySQL server using MySQL Client, run the following command to to view the plugins list:

1mysql -u user -p -e "SHOW plugins"

X DevAPI

The X DevAPI is a new, modern, async developer API for CRUD and SQL operations, built on several technologies including the X Protocol enabled through the X Plugin on top of X Protocol. It wraps powerful concepts in a simple API (such as collections, tables, SQL operations). It can be used to make non-blocking, asynchronous calls that follow common host language patterns. It introduces Collections as new schema objects which is the basis for MySQL document store.

From the developer or application's perspective, the X DevAPI is an the API that (among other things) allows you to develop NoSQL solutions for MySQL and use MySQL as a document store.

Using MySQL as a document store

To interface with MySQL as a document store, you need to have X Plugin installed on MySQL server. If you are using MySQL 8, X Plugin is enabled by default in MySQL 8. Otherwise you have to install or upgrade to MySQL 5.7.12 or higher, then follow this guide to set up MySQL as a document store.

You can't use the old MySQL command-line client to connect to MySQL as a document store, since it doesn't implement the X Protocol. You need MySQL Shell. MySQL Shell is the new modern and advanced command-line client for MySQL. It is a unified scripting interface to MySQL Server. It supports scripting in JavaScript and Python. It can also operate in pure SQL mode. Install MySQL Shell and login to the local MySQL server using the root user using the following command; enter the root password when prompted:

1mysqlsh root@localhost
